Inconsistencies in the article: The expert points out several inconsistencies in the article, such as the jurisdiction of the police departments involved in the arrest and the use of a non-existent police chief's quote. These inconsistencies raise doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
Reverse image search: The expert conducts a reverse image search on the "perp walk" picture mentioned in the article and discovers that it is actually from a different event in July 2011. This finding undermines the credibility of the claim.
Difference in skin tone: The expert notes the difference in skin tone between the man identified as Paul Horner in the mugshot and the obscured man in the "arrest" photo. This discrepancy suggests that the two individuals may not be the same person, casting doubt on the claim.
Reputation of the source: The expert highlights that the National Report, the source of the article, is a well-known fake news outlet that publishes completely false stories. This reputation raises suspicions about the authenticity of the claim and suggests that it may be another fabricated story from the outlet.
